instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1425: What is A1425? A1425 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Early 2013, Late 2012 with EMC 2672, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3190, 820-3462..
definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U4900: What is U4900? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in older(pre-2013) macbooks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Doesn't see ssd
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ssd doesn't appear 
I think they tried a ssd converter on it and now not even its original ssd appear. 
I get 3.3v on J4500 as instructed by its schematics. 
Where should I focus now? 
(Smc...) (<CHIP>U4900</CHIP>....) It goes through <CHIP>U4900</CHIP>. Could the problem be on <CHIP>U4900</CHIP>? 
Device works but ssd doesn't appear at all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Doesn't see ssd
threads.message:
Boot USB macOS and check if internal SSD is at least det4ected in Disk Utility.
This test is good to discard a problem with partitions; like deleted, or APFS.

Check first L4500/10.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Doesn't see ssd
threads.message:
hi,
i already checked it L4500  i wrote above text  ([U]I get 3.3v on J4500[/U] ) so do i need to check <CHIP>U4900</CHIP> (Smc) ?
And also I checked ssd cable and tried diffrent cable but doesnt see ssd. And i checked ssd with different device, it works.


[ATTACH type="full" width="250px"]59690[/ATTACH] [ATTACH type="full" width="443px"]59691[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Doesn't see ssd
threads.message:
"i already checked it L4500"
What about L4510?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Doesn't see ssd
threads.message: Remember to change the view in Disk Utility to show all devices and partitions rather than just valid volumes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Doesn't see ssd
threads.message: I get 3.3v on I4500 and 5v on L4510 but this line cannot be used for SSD. I think it's SATA GUMSTICK2. For normal HDD, I get 3.3v on 1 to 14 on J4500. The owner said that it's been like this since they tried to replace the SSD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Doesn't see ssd
threads.message: Then check for knocked off components, or broken traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Doesn't see ssd
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SATA_SSDRHDD_D2R_P</SIGNAL> , <SIGNAL>SATA_SSDRHDD_D2R_N</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SATA_SSDRHDD_R2D_P</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SATA_SSDRHDD_R2D_N</SIGNAL>
There are 4 lines through the hdd socket, none of which seems damaged.If you could be more explanatory, I can move forward more easily Could you give me directions from the schematics on which path should I take or which lines should I test?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Doesn't see ssd
threads.message:
Check <RESISTOR>R4506</RESISTOR>/07/08/10 and <CAPACITOR>C4517</CAPACITOR>/18/22/25.
Also check diode mode to ground on these lines.

Try known good SSD flex too.
Do not trust new chinese bulshits.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Doesn't see ssd
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Doesn't see ssd
threads.message:
On J4500 from its 20-22 <RESISTOR>R4506</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R4507</RESISTOR> seems to be working. There is line between the socket and resistors. Resistors are in fine shape. 
Also on J4500, 36-38, on <RESISTOR>R4510</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R4508</RESISTOR> there is line to the resistors and they are working as well. 
I checked 4517, 4518, 4522, 4525 capacitors, all are 10nf

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Doesn't see ssd
threads.message: You should check diode mode to ground on data lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Doesn't see ssd
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 71935, member: 682"]
You should check diode mode to ground on data lines.
[/QUOTE]
i checked data line diod mode.  
Ä± wrote above about it On J4500 from its 20-22 <RESISTOR>R4506</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R4507</RESISTOR> seems to be working.    There is line between the socket and resistors

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Doesn't see ssd
threads.message:
SSD data lines have series caps.
Did you check diode mode on the PCH's side of them?
You can also check the other side, when SSD is connected.
